Authors:
Jean-Luc Boeve, Stephan M Blank, Gert Meijer, Tommi
Nyman
Title:
Invertebrate and avian predators as drivers of chemical
defensive strategies in tenthredinid sawflies
Keywords:
Insects, Tenthredinidae larvae, visual signals, deterrent
hemolymph, volatiles, chemical defense, predatory birds and ants,
predatorÂ–prey interactions, diversity, evolution
Abstract:
Background: Many insects are chemically defended against
predatory vertebrates and invertebrates. Nevertheless, our understanding
of the evolution and diversity of insect defenses remains limited, since
most studies have focused on visual signaling of defenses against birds,
thereby implicitly underestimating the impact of insectivorous insects.
In the larvae of sawflies in the family Tenthredinidae (Hymenoptera),
which feed on various plants and show diverse lifestyles, two distinct
defensive strategies are found: easy bleeding of deterrent hemolymph,
and emission of volatiles by ventral glands. Here, we used phylogenetic
information to identify phylogenetic correlations among various
ecological and defensive traits to estimate the relative importance of
avian versus invertebrate predation.
